Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing the landlord’s obligation to keep leased residential premises fit for habitation and that substantial interference with habitability may give rise to tenant remedies); see also Massachusetts landlord-tenant law and related authorities recognizing tenant rights to essential services and remedies where landlords fail to provide them.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (discussing implied warranty of habitability and landlord obligations; cited for principle that lack of essential services may breach landlord’s obligations)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts and defines an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and details the landlord’s obligation to provide and maintain premises that are safe, clean, and fit for human habitation, including essential facilities such as heat, plumbing, and sanitation. It explains that substantial defects in these essential services constitute a breach of the warranty and allow remedies such as rent abatement and damages, which aligns directly with the proposition that lack of essential services may breach the landlord’s obligations.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit…. In determining whether there has been a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, courts should inquire whether the claimed defect has an impact on the safety or health of the tenant.”
